thread.title: NBN Co spends $14 million on new copper
thread.title_full: NBN Co spends $14 million on new copper | Business Spectator

author: Supratim Adhikari
title: NBN Co spends $14 million on new copper
text:
The company building the National Broadband Network (NBN) has bought 1800 kilometres of copper, at a cost of $14 million, to facilitate the fibre-to-the-node (FTTN) component of the network and it’s going to need a lot more of it.
NBN Co chief executive Bill Morrow told a senate estimates hearing in Canberra on Tuesday that Sydney-based Prysmian, the company supplying the new copper, will have to ramp up production as NBN Co deploys new copper to connect the NBN nodes to Telstra’s distribution pillars. The use of new copper to forge this is link is not surprising and Mr Morrow said that so far NBN Co has not had to replace the copper between the nodes and premises.
He added that the condition of Telstra’s existing copper is relatively robust but acknowledged that it’s still too early to make any conclusive assessment.
FTTN technology was launched last month and with 5100 premises currently ready to receive a service, Mr Morrow said that there were currently 58 paying FTTN customers. As of October 8, 2015 there are 619,861 premises active across the entire NBN.
It’s still early days for FTTN and with 1400 nodes in action NBN Co is yet to install the multitude of nodes needed for a successful rollout. As the footprint expands NBN Co will need extra copper to connect the nodes to the pillars and there is a chance that some of it may be required to remediate the parts of the copper network that connect homes to the NBN nodes.
The senate estimates hearing last night was witness to some heated exchanges, especially between former Labor communications minister Senator Stephen Conroy and Mr Morrow.
Senator Conroy’s efforts to table a version of the three-year rollout roadmap issued to the retail service providers led to a significant kerfuffle during the hearings, with NBN Co objecting strongly to the release of the information.
According to Mr Conroy, the roadmap, highlighting estimated ready-for-service dates for different suburbs, presented to the RSPs pointed to significant delays between when the network will be rolled out in an area and when it would be made available to end users.
Mr Morrow said the confidential document was designed to streamline the build process and given the natural delay between when construction in an area translates to real service, a public release of official dates could lead to customer confusion.
Mr Conroy was also highly critical about Mr Morrow's past corporate history.
"People died last time you were in charge of something," he shouted at the CEO during a discussion about the rollout on the NSW Central Coast.
Mr Morrow previously oversaw an American company, which later had two of its pipelines explode, killing nine people.
Committee chair Linda Reynolds described the remark as unparliamentary, inflammatory and highly insulting, and asked Senator Conroy to apologise.
He initially refused, but did so after a short private meeting between committee members.
Mr Morrow also agreed to apologise to Labor's Deborah O'Neill, who had been asking questions about her region at the time.
"I withdraw. I would never speak down to a senator," he said.
During the hearing Palmer United senator Zhenya Wang made a pitch to Mr Morrow to use more Australian companies and minds in deploying satellite technology.
But the CEO conceded the country doesn't have the expertise and experience that companies in the US do.
He nominated a company in California which has been building satellites for space exploration.
Senator Wang replied it would be good to start somewhere.
"Maybe one day we can be launching satellites ourselves," he said.
Mr Morrow agreed, saying: "I would hope so. Let's keep that ambition senator."
On October 1, NBN launched the first of two satellites - Sky Muster - with Australians in rural and regional areas to benefit in the first half of next year.
With AAP
Bill Morrow 2 NO ARCHIVING.jpg
